Title: The effects of managerial, environmental and organizational factors on the performance of strategic planning in industrial plantation forests (Empirical study in HTI companies–islands of Sumatera and Kalimantan)
Affiliations: Faculty of Economics and Business, Accounting Department, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Management Information System, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Sukendar, W.H., Faculty of Economics and Business, Accounting Department, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Abdurachman, E., Management Information System, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Forests are renewable resources. A wood-based industry has competitive advantage and comparative advantage. It becomes the mainstay of economy in Indonesia. As a country that has the second largest forest area in the world, Indonesia got less successful in forest industry plants based Transmigration. This becomes an interesting phenomenon. From the point of previous literature review can be seen that variety aspects related to the impact of the strength of strategic planning and corporate performance such as in studies on the assessment outline controversy and inconsistency in general. Some research groups on strategic planning effectiveness showed positive performance, and another research showed negative performance. However, there has no research related to the strategic planning effectiveness impacts to the performance of the forest industry plants until now. This study aimed to examine the effectiveness of three constructs of strategic planning. The independent variables are managerial, environmental and organizational culture factors in relation to the company performance either directly or indirectly. This research was conducted by collecting questionnaire data from respondents, and was developed the answers from several theories. The results of research described that there is no significant relationship between strategic planning and corporate performance. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Corporate performance; Economy; Effectiveness; Environment; Managerial; Organizational culture; Strategic planning
